The requestAnimationFrame API is widely supported in modern browsers. Using it instead of setTimeout or setInterval for periodic UI updates decreases CPU usage (especially on slower devices) and may also make animations appear more smoothly (no dropped frames).
One class that may benefit from the usage of the requestAnimationFrame API is qx.fx.queue.Queue.
For an introduction to the requestAnimationFrame API, see:
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2011/07/05/using-pc-hardware-more-efficiently-in-html5-new-web-performance-apis-part-1.aspx

Based on a recent discussion on the mailing list [1], I don't think we should spend the time to dig into that. A quick check on caniuse.com also showed, that the set of browsers supporting CSS animations [2] is almost the same as those which support the requestAnimationFrame API [3].
[1] http://qooxdoo.678.n2.nabble.com/questions-about-qx-bom-AnimationJS-td7236442.html;cid=1330933252409-495 [2] http://caniuse.com/#search=css3%20animation [3] http://caniuse.com/#search=requestAnimationFrame
